However, as former head athletic trainer Gary Vitti recently recalled, some members of that iconic "Showtime" era carried their sense of humor to extremes. Name: 1_passed away_grandmother_mary_funeral
Representative_Docs: ['Tosca Theresa Pardini Birth: 1931 Death: 2025 Tosca Theresa Pardini, beloved mother, Nonna, great grandmother, and cherished friend, passed away peacefully on Sunday, November 16, surrounded by the love of her family. On a dark, cloudy day, as the Frank Sinatra song ‚ÄúFly Me to the Moon‚Äù played softly, a single ray of sunshine broke through and gently touched her beautiful face as she took her final breath with her family by her side. She was born at home in San Francisco on May 7, 1931, and she carried the spirit of the city with her throughout her life. Tosca later made her home in Ross, California, where she built a life centered on family, tradition, and enduring love. Tosca met the love of her life, Sergio Pardini, and they were married on February 17, 1952, at Saints Peter and Paul Church in North Beach. For sixty one adventure filled years they were inseparable and shared a deep devotion that guided their lives together. Known for her warmth, elegance, and quiet strength, Tosca created a home where everyone felt welcome. She was deeply proud of her Italian heritage and the traditions she lovingly passed down. Her kindness and grace touched all who knew her. Tosca loved traveling the world with Ser', 'Mary Kuljis Fiamengo Birth: 1934 Death: 2025 Mary Fiamengo passed away peacefully on November 6, 2025. Mary was born on September 20, 1934 in Komiza, Croatia. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband, Pete J. Fiamengo. Mary was a devoted wife, mother, sister, grandmother, great grandmother, aunt and dear friend. She is survived by her daughters, Deborah Dwight and Jennifer (Tim) Lovoy; her grandchildren, Peter Dwight (Cassandra), John Lovoy (Sloane), Ellen (Justin) Ralph and Lauren Dwight (Tim); her great grandchildren, Jordana Koonce, Hank Ralph and Margot Dwight and her sister, Betty Galosic. She was a long standing member of Mary Star of the Sea Church Velike Gospe Society, San Pedro Peninsula Cancer Guild and San Pedro Peninsula Hospital Bookworm Guild. Mary was a woman of grace, elegance and kindness; always extending a gentle word, a thoughtful gesture or a warm embrace. A memorial mass will be held at 10:30 am on Monday, November 17, 2025 at Mary Star of the Sea Catholic Church. In lieu of flowers, Mary requested that a donation in her memory be made to the San Pedro Peninsula Cancer Guild or to Mary Star of the Sea High School. Send Flowers Plant a Tree Send a Meal', 'Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser Birth: 1950 Death: 2025 Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser March 16, 1950-December 15, 2025 passed away peacefully surrounded by her family at her home in San Pancho, Mexico. Survived by her husband of 41 years, Phil Schlosser, her mother Gerry, daughter Kelly Noel, son Kevin Noel and wife Jennifer and her grandchildren Trevor and Lena. She was preceded in death by her father, Wayne Henry Jordan and brother Michael Wayne Jordan. Linda was born and raised in San Rafael, CA and graduated from Terra Linda High School. Linda loved sunshine, warm weather and travel. She was an outstanding cook and loved to entertain. Her great adventure was moving to Mexico, building a wonderful home filled with warmth, family, friends and great meals. She loved traveling throughout Mexico and Italy. Her family requests that gifts in lieu of flowers be made in Linda‚Äôs name to St. Jude Children‚Äôs Research Hospital. Forever deep in my soul, The memory of your love Fills my heart And I am never alone. Honor with Flowers In memory of Linda Sue Plant a Living Memorial In memory of Linda Sue']

Name: 2_passed away_jack_jim_funeral
Representative_Docs: ['John Kevin King Birth: 1956 Death: 2025 John Kevin King of La Habra Heights, California, passed away peacefully on November 5, 2025. He was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma, and was a devoted husband, father, grandfather, and friend. John earned his masters degree in civil engineering from Oklahoma State University and built a respected career marked by professionalism, responsibility, and a steady leadership style. He was known for his integrity, calm presence, and thoughtful approach to his work. He was an avid golfer and a longtime member of Hacienda Golf Club, where he also served as a board member. He valued the friendships, camaraderie, and community he found there. John was preceded in death by his parents, Charlie King and Juanita May King. He is survived by his wife, Allis King, his daughters Megan Branagh and her husband John, and Whitney Dugan and her husband Adam, and his grandchildren Grady, Henry, Wesley, and Georgie Branagh, and Oliver and Charlie Dugan. He loved his wife deeply and was known by many as a genuine and easygoing friend. A Celebration of Life will be held on November 23, 2025, in La Habra Heights, California. The family invites friends and loved ones to join in honoring his mem', 'John Hall Birth: 1933 Death: 2026 John was born October 7, 1933 in Chico, California to John and Alice Hall. He was raised on the family ranch in Cana and then served in the United States Army. After his service in the army he married and spent time in Corning where he worked for an olive plant. He then moved with his family to Chico and spent time working in the rice industry and at Jessup Door Lumber. He also spent some time working for Wieck Automotive. John loved playing his guitar and singing country western music. He enjoyed family, having fun and playing pranks on people. He is predeceased by his parents, 3 siblings and a son Dan Janes. John is survived by his sister Helen Burch, children Linda Field (Steve), Bill Janes (Lynn), Lee Hall (Jackie), Judy Wieck, and numerous grandchildren and great grandchildren which he loved to brag about. John passed away peacefully January 8, 2026 in Sparks, Nevada. A Celebration of Life will be held at 11:00am Saturday, January 31, 2026 at Newton-Bracewell Chico Funeral Home. We will be celebrating our love for John by wearing his favorite clothing style of western attire to his celebration. Please feel free to join us by wearing your western attire.', 'Gerald Joe Dale Brown Birth: 1947 Death: 2025 Gerald (Joe) Dale Brown Gerald (Joe) Dale Brown, 78, of Red Bluff, California passed away at home on October 31, 2025, following a long fight with prostate cancer.Joe was born July 29, 1947, in Red Bluff. He was the son of Maryalice (Parker) and Philip Brown. His early years were spent in Mineral, then as an adolescent, moved to Red Bluff.Joe graduated from Red Bluff High School in 1965, then went on to Chico State University, earning a degree in Business Administration. During his time at Chico State, he was a talented member of the ski team and distinguished for his skill in ski jumping.He built a successful career in the Timber industry, where his hard work and dedication earned him great respect. Later, he transitioned into management for the City of Red Bluff, where he retired. His kindness, integrity and leadership made a lasting impact on colleagues and the community alike.Joe enjoyed spending time in the outdoors golfing, hunting, and camping. He was an avid fisherman and loved spending time in his woodshop woodworking. He was a passionate fan of his beloved San Francisco Giants and 49ers.Remaining to cherish Joe‚Äôs memory are his wife, Mary; children']

Name: 3_family_friendships_family members_friendship
Representative_Docs: ['Asking Eric: I‚Äôm annoyed that friend, IRL, never comments or ‚Äòlikes‚Äô my online posts Dear Eric: I have a friend I‚Äôve known for four years. We all live in a 55+ community and have moved here from different areas of the country. We are a group of women who get together on a regular basis for outings. Over the past couple of months, I feel somewhat left out because of a couple of events I wasn‚Äôt included in. But what I‚Äôm trying to understand is why does she not ‚Äúlike‚Äù or comment on any of my Facebook posts when she‚Äôs all over everyone else‚Äôs with supportive and loving comments? Again, this is so silly, but I can‚Äôt help wondering why. When I look back at my posts, I noticed she has never acknowledged any of them, even for my birthday. We are still friends, we work with the same fundraising group, have dinner at each other‚Äôs house and get invited to the same events. This Facebook thing has got me confused and I don‚Äôt know what kind of friend she is so I‚Äôm getting uncomfortable around her. So now, what am I doing? Ignoring her posts, which makes me feel so stupid and juvenile. If I wasn‚Äôt part of this group, which I really like, I wouldn‚Äôt bother with her. Can you shed any light on her mindset? It‚Äôs really got me confused. ‚Äì Friend Request Dear Friend: Even though social', 'Asking Eric: Can mom work through tension in son‚Äôs relationship with dad so they can celebrate special birthday? Dear Eric: My son is turning 40 on December 22. My husband and I are at a quandary as to how to celebrate him. There have been issues between my husband and him over things from his childhood. We did a special trip for his older brother when he turned 40 and would like to do something special for this son‚Äôs 40th as well. Our daughter-in-law has made special plans for him and we are not included. I understand that, but I need some ideas as to how to celebrate this extra special year without rocking the boat. I love my son with all my heart, as I do all my children, and want his 40th birthday to be memorable in a positive way. Any suggestions? ‚Äì Mom Who Wants to Celebrate Dear Mom: The issues your son and your husband are having may be an obstacle, but they aren‚Äôt insurmountable. And the thing that can get them on the path to resolution is the same thing that can get you answers about how to celebrate your son: open communication. It‚Äôs not within your purview to try to fix things between them, but you have your own relationship with your son and so I‚Äôd encourage you to reach out and tell him what you told me: you want to celebrate him, you know things are difficult, and you‚Äôre lookin', 'Asking Eric: After 6 years sober, man is frustrated by his family‚Äôs hold on their hurt and distrust Dear Eric: I‚Äôve just turned 40 this past year. The last 15 years I was in a horrible drug addiction. I lied and hurt and did terrible things to a lot of people, especially my family. About eight years ago they officially disowned me. Understandable. I‚Äôve cleaned up and got my act together six years ago. At first, I tried to force my way back into their lives, which all refuted. I lashed out, said horrible things and stopped trying to be in their lives. My mom will stop by on my birthday for 10 minutes or so and drop a card off at Christmas. As for my two older brothers and my father, it‚Äôs radio silence. I guess what I‚Äôm asking is, what do I do to fix this and fast, as I said I‚Äôve turned 40 this year, my parents are both 70. Time is running out, and I couldn‚Äôt imagine living my life without some kind of acceptance from my father. Or knowing he did or does love me. My heart breaks at the thought, but this is a real pickle. How can I fix a problem when the ones I need to fix it with won‚Äôt talk to me? Do I just keep ignoring their existence and put on this fa√ßade that I don‚Äôt care to my wife and 4-year-old son? What picture am I painting to my son, as he‚Äôs been guilty by association yo']

Name: 4_brendan_actors_movies_actor
Representative_Docs: ["AP Entertainment SummaryBrief at 3:08 p.m. EST Brendan Fraser's new horizons include 'Rental Family' and rental hedgehogs BEDFORD, N.Y. (AP) ‚Äî ‚ÄúRental Family‚Äù is Brendan Fraser‚Äôs first leading role since winning the best actor Oscar for ‚ÄúThe Whale.‚Äù In it, the 56-year-old plays a struggling actor living in Japan who, out of desperation and curiosity, takes a job with an agency that hires out actors to fulfill roles in real people‚Äôs lives. In an interview, Fraser discusses his life since the Oscar win, his eye-opening experiences in Japan and what returning to the ‚ÄúMummy‚Äù series means to him. His time in Japan included a visit to a hedgehog cafe. ‚ÄúRental Family‚Äù opens Friday in theaters. Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Name: 5_museum_tourism_architecture_arab
Representative_Docs: ["Egypt unveils the world's largest museum dedicated to a single civilization Egypt is inaugurating on Saturday the Grand Egyptian Museum, two decades in the making, with the aim of drawing more visitors to revitalize the country's tourist industry. Located just outside Cairo on the Giza Plateau which also includes the three pyramids and the Sphinx, the museum will be the world‚Äôs largest dedicated to a single civilization. It will display over 50,000 artifacts detailing life in ancient Egypt. World leaders, including monarchs, heads of states and governments, are set to attend the grand opening ceremony, according to the Egyptian presidency which touted the museum as ‚Äúan exceptional event in the history of human culture and civilization.‚Äù The museum is one of the megaprojects championed by President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi since he took office in 2014. He has embarked on massive investments in infrastructure with the aim of reviving an economy weakened by decades of stagnation and battered by the unrest that followed the 2011 Arab Spring uprising. Preparations for the grand reveal have been shrouded in secrecy. The museum, which was opened for limited visits in recent years, has been closed for the past two weeks. Name: 6_welfare_labour_social security_mps
Representative_Docs: ['How much will DWP benefits and pensions rise following the budget? Benefits Budget 2025 Child Benefit Department for Work and Pensions DWP Pensions PIP Rachel Reeves Universal Credit National government Personal Finance DWP benefits including Universal Credit, Child Benefit, PIP, Carer\'s Allowance, and the State Pension are to increase in April 2026 after Rachel Reeves announced higher payments in her budget speech today. Anyone who claims DWP benefits should be in line for an increase in the next financial year, as the chancellor laid out plans to help pensioners, disabled people, parents, low earners, carers and unemployed people keep up with rising costs. Addressing MPs, Ms Reeves said: "The broken welfare system that we inherited wrote off millions of people as too sick to work and we will reform that system so that it is a system that does not count the cost of failure, but one that protects people who cannot work and empowers those who can. "We have brought back face-to-face assessments for disability benefits. Those are the face-to-face assessments that the shadow chancellor (Sir Mel Stride) got rid of when he was work and pensions secretary and our changes we have made to Universal Credit will get 15,000 people back into work, a figure con', 'How much will DWP benefits and pensions rise following the budget? Name: 7_immigration_britain_british_immigrants
Representative_Docs: ['‚ÄòUK public have tougher stance on immigration and diversity than people in US‚Äô People in the UK are less likely than their US counterparts to feel diversity strengthens society and more likely to have tougher attitudes on immigration, according to research. The findings are said to show that a common narrative about Britain being more socially liberal than America does not ring true across all issues. The National Centre for Social Research also found Reform UK voters in Britain were more likely than supporters of President Donald Trump in the US to say immigrants living in their country without permission should not be allowed to stay. While seven in 10 supporters of Mr Trump felt this way, the figure was almost eight in 10 (79%) among Reform followers. The researchers said they wanted to ‚Äúbetter understand how public attitudes in the UK compare with those in the US, and the extent of polarisation in the two countries‚Äù. Their survey found 42% of people in the UK think there should be legal efforts to deport immigrants living here without permission, compared with just a third (33%) in the US. While almost two-thirds (64%) of respondents in the US felt diversity strengthens society, only around half (49%) of the UK public agreed. Proportions were similar when', '‚ÄòUK public have tougher stance on immigration and diversity than people in US‚Äô People in the UK are less likely than their US counterparts to feel diversity strengthens society and more likely to have tougher attitudes on immigration, according to research. The researchers said they wanted to ‚Äúbetter understand how public attitudes in the UK compare with those in the US, and the extent of polarisation in the two countries‚Äù. The National Centre for Social Research also found Reform UK voters in Britain were more likely than supporters of President Donald Trump in the US to say immigrants living in their country without permission should not be allowed to stay. While seven in 10 supporters of Mr Trump felt this way, the figure was almost eight in 10 (79%) among Reform followers. The researchers said they wanted to ‚Äúbetter understand how public attitudes in the UK compare with those in the US, and the extent of polarisation in the two countries‚Äù. Their survey found 42% of people in the UK think there should be legal efforts to deport immigrants living here without permission, compared with just a third (33%) in the US. While almost two-thirds (64%) of respondents in the US felt diversity strengthens society, only around half (49%) of the UK public agreed. Proportions were similar when']

Name: 8_new study_cancer_screening_medical
Representative_Docs: ['Disagreement Between Two Kidney Function Tests Predicts Serious Health Problems NEW YORK and HOUSTON, Nov. 7, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- A mismatch between two common tests for kidney function may indicate a higher risk for kidney failure, heart disease, and death, a new study shows. Health care providers for decades have measured blood levels of the molecule creatinine to track the rate at which kidneys filter waste from muscle breakdown in the bloodstream. According to more recent guidelines, levels of cystatin C, a small protein made by all cells in the body, can also be used to measure kidney function. Since these two tests are influenced by different factors ‚Äî including some related to disease or aging ‚Äî using both markers together can provide a better measure of kidney function and risk of organ failure than either one alone. Since these two tests are influenced by different factors ‚Äî including some related to disease or aging ‚Äî using bo', "Mammograms may reveal hidden heart risks for women, Penn State study finds Routine mammograms are best known as a front-line tool for detecting breast cancer. But new research suggests the same X-ray images may also offer an early warning sign for cardiovascular disease ‚Äî the leading cause of death among women. A study presented at a Dec. 3 Radiological Society of North America meeting found that calcium deposits visible in the arteries of the breast can help predict a woman‚Äôs future risk of heart attack, heart failure, stroke and death. The findings add to growing evidence that mammograms may hold untapped value beyond cancer screening. Javascript is required for you to be able to read premium content. Health care providers for decades have measured blood levels of the molecule creatinine to track the rate at which kidneys filter waste from muscle breakdown in the bloodstream. According to more recent guidelines, levels of cystatin C, a small protein made by all cells in the body, can also be used to measure kidney function. Since these two tests are influenced by different factors ‚Äî including some related to disease or aging ‚Äî using both markers together can provide a better measure of kidney function and risk of organ failure than either one alone. Led by NYU Langone Health researchers, the new work reveals that many people, especially those who are sick, often have a large gap between the two readings, which may be a signal of future disease. Specifically, the global study shows that more than a third of hospitalized participants had a cystatin C-based readout of kidney function that was at least 30% lower than one based on their creatinine levels. Name: 9_royal_andrew_harry_chief executive
Representative_Docs: ['King Charles and Queen Camilla\'s huge move amid Andrew\'s title drama King Charles and Queen Camilla have made a charitable donation to the people of Jamaica after damage caused by Hurricane Melissa\ufeff this week. It was reported that after the monarch shared a statement on how \ufeff"deeply concerned" he was over the weather event, he and his wife made a private donation to the Red Cross for the relief efforts in affected countries. Chief executive of the British Red Cross Beatrice Butsana-Sita said: "King Charles and Queen Camilla\'s donation will help the IFRC network continue its lifesaving work, particularly in Jamaica, such as through search and rescue and ensuring people have access to healthcare, safe shelter, clean water, food and other essential supplies." Secretary General of the IFRC Jagan Chapagain added, "We are very grateful for this donation and hope it will encourage others to donate, too. Hurricane Melissa hit Jamaica hard. Our emergency appeal is essential to raise the funds needed to help people rebuild their lives over the months and years to come." Name: 10_fabric_pigment_carpet_colors
Representative_Docs: ['The darkest fabric ever made is now a dress Get the Popular Science daily newsletterüí° Breakthroughs, discoveries, and DIY tips sent every weekday. Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. There is black, and then there is ultrablack. The shade defined as a black that reflects less than 0.5 percent of the light that hits it, is used on everything from telescopes to cameras. This uniquely dark color is not easy to produce and may appear less black when it is viewed at an angle. To find a better way to reproduce this cool color, a team at Cornell University looked to nature. Specifically, a bird called the magnificent riflebird. The result is the darkest known fabric ever created and it is detailed in a study recently published in the journal Nature Communications. The magnificent riflebird is a large songbird and member of the bird-of-paradise family found in New Guinea and Australia. Male riflebirds are almost completely black, with a green and blue metallic sheen on their belly, throat, and crown feathers. With the help of Mary M. Ferraro and Vanya Rohwer from the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, the team studied the riflebird‚Äôs black feathers. Their plumage comes from melanin pigment paired with tightly bunched filaments called barb', "Sam's Club Is Selling a Versatile 12-Drawer Organizer That's a Serial Hobbyist's Dream Come True As a subscriber, you can share up to 3 articles each month with friends for free. Name: 11_hospital_laboratory_nursing_patients
Representative_Docs: ['HNL Lab Medicine Brings Escape Room Fun to Hospital Education ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 10, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- HNL Lab Medicine is transforming hospital training by turning mandatory education into an adventure. To strengthen the collaboration between laboratory and nursing teams, HNL Lab Medicine\'s Clinical Hospital Advisors have introduced an innovative "escape room"‚Äìstyle educational game that turns essential lab‚Äêrelated lessons into an interactive experience. The escape room begins with a familiar challenge: how to avoid getting a phone call from the lab about a rejected sample. From there, nurses progress through a series of puzzles based on real‚Äêworld scenarios, selecting properly filled blood culture bottles; answering type & screen questions; identifying best practices to prevent clotted or hemolyzed samples; ordering laboratory tubes correctly, and collecting laboratory tubes in the correct order of draw. Each correct answer provides a key or code to unlock the next stage, ultimately leading to a prize. The activity takes less than ten minutes per nurse, no longer than a standard training session, but delivers far more excitement and engagement. The format encourages problem‚Äêsolving, sparks conversation, and helps key lessons stick. Name: 12_strictly_contestants_dancing_chris
Representative_Docs: ["Strictly Come Dancing star confesses to feelings of 'guilt' about winning BBC show Karen Carney, George Clarke and Amber Davies will battle it out for the coveted Glitterball trophy on Strictly Come Dancing this weekend, with YouTuber George currently leading as the bookmakers' favourite. Yet the competition doesn't always go according to plan, with the BBC ballroom series having witnessed numerous surprising outcomes throughout its history. The 2009 series delivered one of the programme's most unexpected moments when Chris Hollins defied the odds to triumph over favourite Ricky Whittle. The victory surprised many, with the presenter later admitting he felt somewhat guilty about his win too. Hollyoaks actor Ricky, partnered with professional dancer Natalie Lowe, had regularly out-danced Chris, who performed alongside Ola Jordan. Nevertheless, Chris garnered substantial support from the viewing public and whilst he wasn't receiving the highest judges' scores, he consistently progressed through public votes, never facing elimination in the dance-off. Ultimately, he claimed victory, reports Wales Online. Prior to the finale, Chris acknowledged feeling a little guilty about reaching the last stage instead of Ali Bastian and Brian Fortuna, who had achieved better scor", 'Strictly Come Dancing fans have same complaint as La Voix withdraws from show \'Pointless!\' Strictly Come Dancing fans have been left with the same question after it was announced La Voix has withdrawn from the competition. During Saturday (November 22) night\'s show, the remaining contestants took to the dance floor at the iconic Blackpool Tower Ballroom. Before things kicked off for Blackpool Week, presenter Tess Daly informed viewers that the drag queen ‚Äì real name Chris Dennis ‚Äì would not be returning to the competition after sustaining a foot injury. She said: "We can confirm she has very sadly had to withdraw from the competition," before revealing there would be no elimination this weekend. But this has left fans wondering why Sunday night\'s show is still airing now that there is no dance-off. Taking to social media with their queries, one wrote: "So what‚Äôs the point of Sunday‚Äôs show when everything can be done tonight #Strictly?" You', 'Strictly Come Dancing star breaks silence after concern fifth contestant would quit Strictly Come Dancing\'s Alex Kingston is poised to carry on with her dance adventure, putting to rest concerns she might have to withdraw due to injury. The 62-year-old actress had triggered concerns about a potential exit after her daughter disclosed a rib injury on social media, stating that her mother had endured the discomfort to participate in Saturday\'s programme. The Doctor Who legend, who has been dazzling audiences on the dance floor alongside partner Johannes Radebe, was swift to comfort her supporters that injuries were simply "part and parcel" of the Strictly experience, and she had absolutely no plans to retire her dancing shoes. Fleur East, host of Strictly spin-off It Takes Two, has now verified that Alex will return to the competition following last week\'s Blackpool special. Discussing their forthcoming performance, Fleur disclosed: "Alex and Johannes will be dancing a cha-cha-cha to Ring My Bell by Anita Ward." Name: 13_africa_school students_south africa_tourists
Representative_Docs: ['Minnesota high schoolers prepare for once-in-lifetime learning trip to Africa ASHBY, Minn. ‚Äî There are field trips and there are field trips. Students at Ashby High School are busy raising money and getting ready to pack their bags for a two-week learning experience in South Africa. ADVERTISEMENT When it is below zero, the main street in Ashby, Minnesota, is quiet. Fewer than 500 people call this Grant County town home, but lately the town is busy rallying around a group of high school students. In the basement of Peace Grue Lutheran in the middle of town, five high school students join veteran church quilters in tying quilts that the students will take on their trip to South Africa. "There is a reason the church ladies do this and not the guys," joked Kevin Fick, the girls\' weightlifting coach and organizer of the trip, of tying quilts the students will take with them as gifts. Five girls, along with Fick and four adult chaperones, will make the trip to Eastern Cape, South Africa, from Feb. 28 through March 10. Not as tourists, but to learn about conservation on another continent. "Not a lot of kids get to do this," said student Hadley Hokanson, student. They will work a sheep ranch, fish for sharks, harvest their own food, camp in the bushes and more.
